query: What evidence is most damaging to Gulfstream's defense?
output:
CLAUDE CODE ANALYSIS
Query: What evidence is most damaging to Gulfstream's defense?

RELEVANT DOCUMENT EXCERPTS:

[Bassim Draft Witness Statement.docx, p.1]
CITIOM purchased the Gulfstream G550 aircraft bearing MSN 5174 (the “Aircraft”) in late 2018 / early 2019 from NetJets. [See CITE EVIDENCE OF PURCHASE].

[Bassim Draft Witness Statement.docx, p.1]
Gulfstream also performed maintenance on the Aircraft in July-August 2023, which was the last maintenance performed by Gulfstream before the 192-month inspection. [See CITE EVIDENCE]. This involved work on the leading edges and the APU area. I believe corrosion issues later found during the 192-month inspection should have been identified and addressed during this July 2023 maintenance or even during the 144-month inspection.

[Bassim Draft Witness Statement.docx, p.1]
Around the end of February 2024, I first learned the Aircraft's maintenance would not be complete until mid-late April 2024. [CITE EVIDENCE]. As a result, I had to rearrange certain of my plans to use the Aircraft. This initial delay was disappointing but seemed manageable.

[Leonard Beauchemin Outline #1.docx, p.1]
Confront with evidence that Gulfstream did not use its own July 2023 analytics tool to revise SN5174’s forecast before Jan 2024 input.

[111-206.pdf, p.11]

significant corrosion findings. Similar to #1 above, was there any prior evidence and/or what

[Closing Summary .docx, p.1]
CITIOM entrusted Gulfstream with its most valuable aviation asset, based on a quote that promised a return-to-service by April 1, 2024. That quote—2,800 hours and 35–45 business days—was not just inaccurate. It was misleading.
